docs.lead_paragraph: This history of health policy and the Oval Office shows that the presidents who made the biggest steps in the direction of universal care have acted despite their economic advisers.

headline.seo: Book Review | 'The Heart of Power: Health and Politics in the Oval Office,' by David Blumenthal and James A. Morone

docs.snippet: This history of health policy and the Oval Office shows that the presidents who made the biggest steps in the direction of universal care have acted despite their economic advisers.

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's labor unions seem to be approaching this Labor Day more as Health Reform Lobbying Day than as a traditional holiday. With President Obama scheduled to speak at a union-sponsored picnic in Cincinnati on Monday, labor advocates are spending the weekend painting and printing signs in support of a health care overhaul. That includes labor's pet provision: the public-insurance option. Thirty thousand union members are expected at the picnic.

headline.main: On Day Off, a Day of Work

docs.abstract: Nation's labor unions are approaching Labor Day as opportunity to lobby for health care reform, notably at labor-sponsored Cincinnati, Ohio, picnic where Pres Obama is scheduled to appear; unions want to push wavering Democrats to support health care plan and press Pres Obama to push plan more vigorously; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The nation's labor unions seem to be approaching this Labor Day more as Health Reform Lobbying Day than as a traditional holiday.      With President Obama scheduled to speak at a union-sponsored picnic in Cincinnati on Monday, labor advocates are...

docs.lead_paragraph: The year 2013. That is when everyone would be required to have health insurance under the House health care bill. It may seem like the far distant future -- especially for those who do not have insurance now. But many experts say it is not nearly enough time to build the supply of doctors needed to care for the additional tens of millions of people who would become newly insured.
docs.abstract: Many health experts say there is not nearly enough time to build supply of doctors needed to care for additional tens of millions of people who would become insured by 2013, when House health bill would require everyone to have coverage; Assn of American Medical Colleges projects shortage of 124,000 physicians by 2025 even without reform, which would increase that figure by 25 percent; graph (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans are deeply torn about the prospect of a health care overhaul, according to an analysis of 22 recent nationwide public opinion polls by two professors at the Harvard School of Public Health. The majority of Americans favor the abstract concept of remaking the medical system, according to the analysis, published recently in The New England Journal of Medicine. But at the same time, the study found, the majority believes that if Congress were to enact health care legislation, neither the overall quality of medical care nor their own personal care would improve.
docs.abstract: Analysis of 22 nationwide public opinion polls published in New England Journal of Medicine finds majority of Americans favor abstract concept of remaking medical system, but also believe Congressional health care legislation will not improve overall quality of care or their own personal care (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: 2013. That's the year everyone would have to have health insurance under the House version of the health care bill. It may seem like the far distant future - especially if you don't have insurance now - but many experts say it's not nearly enough time to beef up the supply of physicians necessary to care for the tens of millions suddenly entering the health care system.

headline.main: Who Will Care for the Newly Insured?

docs.abstract: In the coming years, tens of millions of Americans may gain access to health insurance -- but perhaps not to doctors.
docs.snippet: In the coming years, tens of millions of Americans may gain access to health insurance -- but perhaps not to doctors.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even as lawmakers prepare for what is sure to be a grueling fall dominated by efforts to build consensus around an overhaul of the health care system, President Obama shifted attention to another subject for a second consecutive week in his Saturday morning address. Highlighting workers on the Labor Day weekend, the president announced new initiatives he says will make it easier for American families to save for retirement.
docs.abstract: Highlighting the economy and workers on the holiday weekend.
docs.snippet: Highlighting the economy and workers on the holiday weekend.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Labor Day weekend may be fairly labor-intensive for anyone watching the debate on health care.

headline.main: For Interest Groups, It's No Holiday Weekend

docs.lead_paragraph: A Minnesota bus factory that became a symbol of the stimulus when Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. visited has had to lay off workers after cutbacks in Illinois delayed orders.

headline.seo: Bus Factory, Symbol of the Stimulus, Now Laying People Off
headline.main: States Cut Back and Layoffs Hit Even Recipients of Stimulus Aid
headline.print_headline: A Story of Stimulus Success Ends Instead With Pink Slips
